Award.AwardTitle: A New Era for Discrete and Computational Geometry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computational Geometry is a branch of the theory of computer science that studies algorithms for problems best stated in geometric form. The problems arise from applications in Geographic Information Systems, robotics, computer-aided design & manufacturing, computer graphics, data analytics and visualization, molecular modeling, engineering simulation, etc. Computational Geometry was a young field in 1986 when Goodmann and Pollack (NYU) launched what would become the flagship journal, "Discrete & Computational Geometry," with a scientific conference in Santa Cruz. It, and follow-up conferences at Mt. Holyoke (1996), Monte Verita (1999), and Snowbird (2006), had a huge impact in defining and directing the field. This project supports US participants, mainly young researchers, in a scientific conference, "A New Era of Discrete and Computational Geometry," at the ETH Zurich seminar center Monte Verita, in Ascona, Switzerland. It is fitting to revisit Monte Verita in 2016 to review this field's history and look to its future; junior researchers especially will benefit -- learning context from the review, and becoming equipped to create the future.

Joint support from NSF's office of International Science and Engineering and from Computer and Information Science and Engineering broadens the opportunity for US-based participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The subject of the conference, Discrete & Computational Geometry, was created thirty years ago, by joining the classical mathematical field of Discrete Geometry with the then emerging computer science discipline of Computational Geometry. The marriage has proved to be fruitful: A new generation of researchers treats deep problems from one side, with insights, tools and theory that arose on the other side - with great successes. Discrete Geometry and Computational Geometry both deal with fundamental problems about arrangements of the most basic geometric objects (points, lines, planes, convex bodies, etc.) in the plane, in three-space, and in higher dimensions. The solution of important algorithmic tasks is often based on detailed structural information about the underlying configurations, and involves the exact or asymptotic solution of extremal problems. This requires the combination of powerful algorithmic tools and deep techniques from extremal graph theory, algebraic geometry, probability theory, topology, and data structures. The application areas include computer graphics, computer vision, molecular biology, geographic information systems, robotics, medical imaging. The meeting brought together key researchers and promising young colleagues to assess the state of the art and discuss further steps and directions. This was the main objective of the conference, and it was perfectly achieved.

The total number of participants was 92. They came from 19 countries (Austria, China, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, India, Iran, Israel, Japan, Mexico, Netherlands, Romania, Russia, United Kingdom, United States, South Korea, Switzerland, Ukraine, Vietnam). Among the participants there were 12 female scientists, and 31 young researchers (under 35 years). Congressi Stefano Franscini sponsored an award for the best presentation by a young scientist. The winner was Leonardo Martinez-Sandoval (Ben Gurion University, Beer Sheva). The title of his presentation was: A Hall-type theorem for points in general position.

The Organizing Committee consisted of six people: Pankaj K. Agarwal (Duke University), Kenneth L. Clarkson (IBM Almaden), Herbert Edelsbrunner (IST Wien), Janos Pach (EPFL, Lausanne), Emo Welzl (ETH Zürich), and Günter M. Ziegler (Freie Universität Berlin).

The scientific program consisted of twenty 45 minutes long survey talks given by internationally recognized leaders of the field. In addition, we organized a well attended 90 minutes long public lecture by Jin Akiyama (Tokyo University of Science) on “Tilings and reversibilities of figures”, and six shorter presentations by young researchers on very recent results and work in progress, such as tight bounds on epsilon-nets, the relation between the number of trapezoidal diagrams and prime Catalan numbers, generalizations of the joints problem, and a fast contour tree algorithm.
